instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.C6990: What is C6990? Capacitor to ground on input to PP3V42_G3H power supply. PP3V42_G3H power supply turns 18.5v from charger or 8.5v-12.5v PPBUS_G3H from the battery into PP3V42_G3H. This capacitor can short to ground and keep PP3V42_G3H from turning on which would keep the machine from having a light on the magsafe charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 5.1v.
threads.message:
Hello Gents

Received a unit that doesn't power up. Only history i have was that someone was trying to work on the board and messed it up while trying to remove the screws. Trackpad cable is all messed up. <RESISTOR>R7745</RESISTOR> was turn off, Also <CAPACITOR>C6408</CAPACITOR>. 
I've replaced <RESISTOR>R7745</RESISTOR>, since <CAPACITOR>C6408</CAPACITOR> deals with speaker, decided to hold off till i restored power.

So far, the only voltage measurements i've gotten are:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>: 5.19
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBIS</SIGNAL>: 5.19

Any suggestions?
thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 5.1v.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> present?
Check diode mode to ground on F7000.
Probably problem with <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips from USB-C power input.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 5.1v.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 5.1v.
threads.message:
Ooops, even if <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips are good, SMC is not working.
You need <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> first.
Diode mode to ground?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 5.1v.
threads.message: PPBUS will always be missing if DC-in is 5 volts. As 2informaticos asked, diode mode on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>? Resistance to ground in ohms would be ok too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 5.1v.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 5.1v.
threads.message:
Post <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> voltages; pins 2, 10, 1, 3, 9.
Do you have short at <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR>/91?
Could be bad <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, or <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
Don't forget to check <RESISTOR>R6906</RESISTOR> and <DIODE>D6905</DIODE>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 5.1v.
threads.message:
<CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
1 - 0
2 - 5.04
3 - 0
5 - 0
10 - 0

<RESISTOR>R6906</RESISTOR> - 5.19
<DIODE>D6905</DIODE> pin 1 - 0.4, pin2 - 5.18

So when i plug the battery, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is now about 10v, but only with the battery,

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 5.1v.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 5.1v.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 5.1v.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 5.1v.
threads.message: Finally got back to this and yes, <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> did restore power. Thanks for the assist.
